intro: Oncidium huntleyanum, commonly known as the Huntley's orchid, is a tropical orchid native to Central and South America. It is characterized by its pendant, showy inflorescences that bear numerous small, colorful flowers in shades of yellow, orange, and red. The plant typically grows as an epiphyte, attaching itself to tree trunks and branches in its natural habitat. Its roots are adapted to absorb moisture and nutrients from the air and rain. Oncidium huntleyanum requires bright, indirect light and well-draining potting media to thrive in cultivation.
